questions.stem: Which PACE s.24 'necessity' ground most directly covers arresting someone because you cannot readily ascertain their name and address?

options.text: To allow the prompt and effective investigation of the offence
To prevent the person causing physical injury to themselves or others
To ascertain the person's name and/or address (where it cannot be readily ascertained)
Because arrest is always required for indictable offences

questions.explanation: PACE s.24 requires that arrest is necessary. One necessity ground is where the person's name or address cannot be readily ascertained (or is doubted). Arrest is not automatic for offence type; necessity must be justified.

references.cite: PACE 1984 s.24 (powers of arrest and necessity)
Code G — necessity and alternatives to arrest (Check: paragraph)

questions.stem: A client was arrested but says they were never told why. Which PACE provision is most directly relevant to the duty to inform a person they are under arrest and the grounds?

options.text: PACE 1984 s.24
PACE 1984 s.28
PACE 1984 s.76
PACE 1984 s.58

questions.explanation: PACE includes a duty to inform the person they are under arrest and the grounds for arrest. This is central to the lawfulness of arrest and subsequent detention. (In practice you would check the custody record and officer notes for what was said and when.)

references.cite: PACE 1984 s.28 (information to be given on arrest) (Check: exact wording)

questions.stem: Why is identifying the 'relevant time' important when advising in custody?

options.text: It determines which officer is responsible for the investigation
It determines when detention time limits and review obligations start running
It determines whether the offence is indictable
It determines the client's eligibility for legal aid

questions.explanation: Time limits and review points are calculated from the relevant time (as defined in PACE). Getting this wrong can lead to unlawful over‑detention going unnoticed. As a PSR, you should confirm the relevant time from the custody record and cross-check any delays.

references.cite: PACE 1984 (detention time limits from relevant time) (Check: provision)
Code C — recording relevant time and detention reviews (Check: paragraph)

questions.stem: A superintendent extension to detention beyond the initial limit is being considered. What should you do first as a PSR?

options.text: Do nothing until the extension is granted, then advise
Immediately demand release without checking the record
Check the custody record for authorisations, reviews, disclosure of reasons, and make representations if appropriate
Tell your client to refuse all further questions from police

questions.explanation: Extensions require lawful criteria and proper recording/authorisation. Your first step is to inspect the custody record, understand the reason for continued detention and any investigative steps outstanding, then make focused representations and document issues.

references.cite: Code C — detention reviews and extensions (Check: paragraph)

questions.stem: Which is the best reason to routinely inspect the custody record during detention?

options.text: To find out what the police think of your client
To identify rights issues, review timings, and whether decisions/authorisations are properly recorded
To ensure the officer in the case is replaced
To obtain full evidence and witness statements as a right

questions.explanation: The custody record is the procedural backbone of detention: rights and entitlements, reviews, meals/rest, requests (legal advice, AA, interpreter), and reasons for key decisions. Regular inspection helps spot breaches early.

references.cite: Code C — custody record requirements and access (Check: paragraph)

questions.stem: A client says they asked for legal advice hours ago, but no solicitor has attended and the custody record is unclear. What is the best immediate action?

options.text: Proceed with interview anyway to avoid delays
Ask the custody officer to document the request time, steps taken, and any reasons for delay; request interview is not started until advice is provided (unless a lawful exception applies)
Assume the client is exaggerating and take no steps
Tell the client to complain after release; it cannot affect the interview

questions.explanation: Access to legal advice is a core safeguard. You should ensure the custody record accurately reflects the request and what happened next, clarify any claimed exceptions, and prevent interview from proceeding without advice where appropriate.

references.cite: Code C — legal advice requests, delays, and exceptions (Check: paragraph)

questions.stem: When advising about the lawfulness of continued detention, which evidence source is usually the best starting point for verifying key timings and decisions?

options.text: The investigating officer’s recollection
The custody record (including review entries and authorisations)
A social media post about the arrest
The charging standard for the offence

questions.explanation: For detention legality, the custody record is the authoritative procedural record. It should show rights, reviews, timing, and authorisations. If it’s incomplete or inconsistent, that itself may be significant and should be documented.

references.cite: Code C — custody record and detention management (Check: paragraph)
